This guy is either lazy or careless and didn't read the replies to his
original email.  If the JUnit API docs, the cook's tour, the source
code(!!), suggested UML reverse-engineering tools, and the MIT
professor's paper we sent him a link to (which goes into gory detail on
the relationships of JUnit's classes), aren't enough, what would be?

"searched all over the web" -- yeah, right.

Scott Stirling

> -----Original Message-----
> From: Michael Silverstein [mailto:msilverstein@...] 
> Sent: Saturday, October 12, 2002 8:55 AM
> To: junit@yahoogroups.com
> Subject: RE: [junit] junit structure
> 
> 
> The best way I've found to determine the structure of a 
> system is to sit down with a debugger or a profiler and 
> watch/trace exactly what happens when you use some part of 
> the system. It is tedious but there is no substitute for 
> seeing the gears turn.
> 
> It seems like you are looking for detailed information on 
> JUnit's implementation. Is there a particular goal driving 
> this, such as extending the framework? If so, please share 
> with us because many of us have experience with this and can 
> assist, given specific requirements.
> 
> ^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^
> Mike Silverstein
> 
> > -----Original Message-----
> > From: nodoubt1222 [mailto:nodoubt1222@...]
